attributes.description: Supreme deity void of all fear, compared to Ráma's fearlessness
Light's Queen clings to Sun as Ráma to Sítá, swords rival sun in sheen
King of Gods who pours grateful rain, Dasharatha compared to Indra, ruler of Gods' celestial sphere
Lord who gave two fearful celestial bows to Janak at famed rite
Creator, sphere more glorious than others, speaks to ruler of Gods, first created Brighu and Angiras
Goddess of wealth and prosperity, love shown in Ráma's bright abode
Fire God, worship due to him shown to Suyajña
Force whose favor must be won through duty
Hero of stately breast, strong-armed chief, glorious Lord of Light, son of Raghu, prince of men, speaks gentle words, void of fear, will guard Sítá in woods
Daughter of Videha's king, lady of lovely brow/eyes, soft frame, beauteous-armed, faultless form, Ráma's wife, trembler with bright eyes, great love impels to follow
Faithful brother, son of Sumitrá, earnest in prayer, hero just and dear, long-armed Prince of Raghu's line, devoted, carries bow and quiver
King, lord of earth of mighty power, monarch, sire whose orders require obedience, captive in passion's chain
Queen, honored mother, royal dame Ráma's mother, needs protection and comfort, bereft of darling son
Queen, daughter of Ashvapati, proud queen who won imperial power for Bharat, little heeds rivals' needs
Queen, mother of Lakshmana, dear mother, needs care
Prince, ruler of land to be raised as king, stands by Kaikeyí, must provide for queens with love and care
Son of Vasishtha, of Bráhman race, first and holiest one, wise, knew Scripture, found in hall of Fire, performed noonday rites
Best of Bráhmans to whom Ráma gives precious gifts like fostering floods
Best of Bráhmans, likely Vishvámitra, to receive gifts
Deep in Scripture, serves Kausalyá with blessing and respect, true to queen
Tuneful bard and charioteer, true and dear, ancient friend and minister of Ráma
Numerous band who go with staff in hand, trained, prize deep study, love dainty fare, praised by good
Aged Bráhman born of Garga's race, long in evil case, earned living with spade and plough, poor with many children
Young wife who bore babes, felt indigence, counseled husband to seek Ráma
Divine Prajápati first created by Brahmá, bright with saintly light
Divine Prajápati first created by Brahmá, bright with saintly light
Woman who gave all to Satyaván in heart/body/soul/mind, exemplar of wifely devotion
Son of Dyumatsena, husband to whom Sávitrí was devoted
Father of Satyaván
Father of Kaikeyí
Wilderness full of woes: snakes, scorpions, flies, thorny trees, tangled grass, where elephant and roebuck roam, pathless wild, lonely shade, greenwood
Bright dwelling rich in Lakshmí's love, five courts, where treasures distributed, where Sítá prepared to give wealth
Teacher's hall where celestial arms preserved with care
Chapel where sacred fire used in worship is kept, where Suyajña found
Kingdom of Sítá's father Janak, fair land with wide domains
River with banks where herds of kine fed, farther bank where Trijata's staff landed
Dwelling in grove where cows driven, home of poor Bráhman
Homes of Gods, celestial sphere ruled by Indra, worlds where devoted sons win place, Brahmá's glorious sphere
Woes of wilderness: snakes, scorpions, grasshoppers, flies, thorny bushes, tangled grass, fatigue, countless fears, grief and pain
Penance with every thought, no fear of things to fear, forever drear, coat of bark and matted hair, roots/fruit/honey as food
Woman follows husband as Sávitrí followed Satyaván, wife committed to husband in heart/body/soul/mind, husband is God
Truth-declaring Bráhmans foretold Sítá's fortune to dwell in wood, knew future by marks and signs
Ancient teaching that woman given by parents with holy rites is wife in this world and after life
Supreme duty to obey sire and mother, triple world comprises father/mother/holy guide, sonly love and reverence storms heaven
Two fearful bows given by Varuna to Janak, sword-proof mail, quivers with arrows that never fail, golden-hilted swords keen as sun
Gold, silver, gems, pearls, necklaces, girdles, bracelets, beds, elephants, thousand coins, kine given to Bráhmans and servants
Worn by those who wait on Kausalyá with care, mark of Bráhman status
Ráma described perils: snakes, scorpions, thorny trees, hope/anger cast aside, penance required, deemed Sítá unfit
Lady with deep distress begged to accompany, cited love, father's command, Bráhmans' prophecy, threatened death if refused
Daughter of Videha's king accused Ráma of being woman in disguise, likened to low actor, spirit tried by fear/anger/love/pride
Hero's heart reconciled to take Sítá to Dandaka, embraced wife, sweet words bid her wake to life, approved her going
Brother pressed Ráma's feet with fervor, begged to follow to woods with bow, would go before, carry basket/spade, guard sleeping
Commanded brother to bid adieu, bring celestial bows from preceptor's hall, summon Suyajña, bestow wealth on Bráhmans
Ráma honored Suyajña with gems/pearls, gave gifts to Agastya/Kushika's son/Bráhmans/servants, distributed gold/silver/cows/elephants
Poor aged Bráhman came to fifth court, described poverty, Ráma tested with staff-throw, gave thousand kine and wealth
Sítá and princes with celestial arms went to monarch's house, crowds gathered on houses/terraces mourning

attributes.context: Ráma is husband, lord, embraced wife, will guard her in woods, clings to her as Sun's Queen to Sun
Sítá is wife of lovely brow/eyes, resigned in heart/body/soul/mind, husband is God to her, thinks of naught but him
Sítá deems forest woes not pain through love, each woe a charm, each loss a gain
Ráma warned of snakes, scorpions, thorny trees, countless fears in wilderness
Lady with deep distress begged earnestly to follow to woods
Ráma spoke to appal with perils, deemed Sítá unfit for forest
Sítá accused Ráma of being woman in disguise, spirit tried by emotions
Hero's heart reconciled, embraced wife, approved her going to woods
Truth-declaring Bráhmans foretold Sítá's fortune to dwell in forest
Sítá embodies devotion like Sávitrí, resigned to husband in all ways
Sítá cited ancient text that lawfully wedded wife belongs in this world and after
Sítá compared herself to Sávitrí who gave all to Satyaván
Sávitrí devoted to husband Satyaván in heart/body/soul/mind
Satyaván is son of Dyumatsena
Ráma upholds supreme duty to obey father's orders, sire is deity on earth
Ráma void of fear as Self-existent God can be
Ráma will cling to Sítá as Light's Queen true to Sun
Ráma obeys sire's behest, father's orders guide him, will not transgress
Lakshmana is faithful brother, hero just and dear, loved as life, will guard sleeping
Brother pressed feet with fervor, begged to follow with earnest prayer
Ráma at first denied with soothing words, then granted permission
Lakshmana joined them there, heard converse of pair, will accompany
Ráma concerned for honored mother's protection, she bereft of darling son
Lakshmana asked to protect honored mother from neglect
Lakshmana is son of good/dear Sumitrá who needs care
Bharat will stand by Queen Kaikeyí's side as ruler
Bharat must provide love and care for queens through Ráma's might
Kaikeyí is daughter of Ashvapati
King captive in passion's chain to proud queen
Lakshmana brought heavenly arms from preceptor's hall to Ráma
Ráma to use fearful bows, sword-proof mail, arrows that never fail
Varuna gave two fearful celestial bows to Janak at famed rite
Arms preserved with care in Ráma's teacher's hall
Lakshmana commanded to bid adieu, bring arms, summon Suyajña
Ráma honored Suyajña with gems, gave to Bráhmans/servants, distributed treasures
Sítá gave much wealth to Bráhmans, prepared to give treasures away
Lakshmana aided in parting treasures displayed
Suyajña received necklace, girdle, bracelets, bed, elephant Victor, thousand gold coins
Ráma honored wise Suyajña with worship due to Agni, precious gifts
Ráma to rain precious gifts on best of Bráhmans like fostering floods
Ráma to give thousand kine, costly gems, gold and silver to best Bráhman
Chief deep in Scripture serves Kausalyá with blessing and respect
Ráma gives gems, robes, wealth to tuneful bard, ancient friend and minister
Ráma bestows eighty cars loaded with treasures, bulls, elephants, kine on numerous band
Aged poor Bráhman came to court, described poverty, staff-throw test
Ráma jested with staff-throw, gave thousand kine, herdsmen, wealth for sacrifice
Young wife bore babes, felt indigence, counseled husband to seek Ráma
Cows driven to Trijata's dwelling in grove
Trijata's staff sank to earth on Sarjú's farther bank where kine fed
Worship shown to Suyajña was that due to Agni
Suyajña found in hall of Fire where sacred fire kept
Ráma's abode rich in love Lakshmí showed
Brahmá first created Brighu as divine Prajápati
Brahmá first created Angiras as divine Prajápati
Ráma spoke to Lakshmana as Brahmá speaks to ruler of Gods' sphere
Ráma dwells in bright abode with five courts rich in Lakshmí's love
Sítá hastened within to give wealth away
Ráma to make woods his home, dwell in Dandaka pathless wild
Sítá's fortune to dwell in wood, will go with Ráma to greenwood shade
Lakshmana will take bow and go in path before Ráma to forest
Sítá is daughter of Videha's king, pride of Janak's line
Ráma with Sítá and princes went to monarch's house with celestial arms
Sítá went with princes, arms adorned by her beautifying hand
Lakshmana sole friend attended on Ráma's steps with Sítá
